That's why I say LGPE is the best pokemon game on the switch in terms of graphics (aside from NewSnap but looking good is Snap's only job).

They went with making a more stylised/vibrant cartoon world instead of the more grounded and neutral look that SWSH/SV went for, meaning that the vibrant cartoon monsters look like a natural part of the world and not something out of place. Plus having a fixed camera meant they didn't have to worry about how things would be seen from all-angles or up-close, resulting in a more consistent visual experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Potential Status Rework:
So some baseline concepts I set out to address:
>Sleep: if abusable, is a pain in the ass.
Original gamefreak fix: lower accuracy of sleep moves, greatly limit distribution of consistent sleep. Issue mostly hinges on the inability to act coupled with RNG of when you wake.
>Paralysis: Sleep's shithead cousin
Use as a slowdown status is great, but the RNG chance to do nothing at all makes paralysis inconsistent and makes the rewards for inflicting it not something to plan around.
>Freeze: Sleep but different (they really were preoccupied with ways to take away turns in Gen 1, weren't they?)
A status with no status move, meaning it MUST be inflicted by chance. Underutilized, RNG-reliant. I think I've seen two dozen actual Freezes in my entire career, and I've played since Gold release.
>Burn: Okay status
No notes.
>Poison: Toxic is good but limited in use, and base poison is pretty shit
These are the focuses of my initial rework, as I was not too preoccupied with volatile status like Confusion or Attraction - they occupy the same niche as Paralysis, and get more complex.
I set out with the intention to make status less of an RNG fest and more of a conscious choice and reward.

So my first thoughts were to incorporate the changes proposed by PLA.
>Drowsy
Excellent mechanic, but again leans on the RNG aspect. I've removed this and adapted it.
>Frostbite
Fixed Freeze. No way about it. Excellent design.

And I came up with a system to inflict status to allow more ways to interact with them without needing to fuck around with actual status moves or random chance effects.

1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912369
>Sleep
Grass types are immune to drowsy / sleep
>No point system. Solely tied to status moves. Moves that would inflict Sleep now inflict Drowsy. Drowsy Pokemon hit with these moves are put to Sleep.
This makes Sleep an easily achievable goal two-punch goal, and balances the opportunity cost of the status with the potential benefit to be gained.
>Drowsy
>Drowsy Pokemons' moves have a flat 10% accuracy reduction (for example, a 90% accuracy move is now 80% accuracy). Additionally, Drowsy Pokemon take 25% increased damage from the next hit they receive after becoming Drowsy
An immediate payoff for investing the time to inflict Drowsy, but nothing crazy.
>Sleep
Sleep turns now follow this setup:
>Turn 1: Fast Asleep, no chance to awake. Moves like Sleep Talk still work.
>Turn 2: 65% chance to wake, move used on waking has 75% of base accuracy. This works out to turn 2 being a 50/50 of waking AND hitting your waking move.
>Turn 3: 100% chance to wake, no changes to accuracy
>Pokemon leaving Sleep are returned to Drowsy status, and cannot be put to Sleep for 3 turns.
>Accuracies of moves used against Sleeping Pokemon are increased by a flat 5%.

So, now Sleep is a telegraphed, earned status that has a lot going on under the hood rather than just being "you can't move for 2-4 turns". This all works out to:
>Invest two turns to put an opposing Pokemon to sleep
>As a result, it is expected the opposing Pokemon will have approx. 1.5 of the next 3 turns to use, a net loss of 1-2 turns.
>And even after waking, the Pokemon remains weakened in a Drowsy state.

This is all a little heavily designed, but Sleep really wasn't well thought-out and never has been. Hiding behind low-accuracy moves doesn't change how busted sleep is fundamentally.

2/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912381
>Paralysis
Fighting types are immune to dazed/paralysis
>No longer centered around electric types - now based around Flinches and Critical Hits
This makes Paralysis an evergreen status, something heavily needed by non-elemental types.
>Dazed
>Pokemon that have been flinched or critically hit become dazed. Dazed Pokemon lose 25% Speed. Moves used against Dazed Pokemon have increased critical hit ratios. Flinching or Critting a Dazed Pokemon pushes this status to Paralyzed
>Paralyzed
>Speed reduced 50%, Priority moves used by Paralyzed Pokemon lose 1 priority.
>Moves against Paralyzed Pokemon have even higher critical hit ratios
>Accuracies of moves used against Paralyzed Pokemon are increased by a flat 10%

This makes Paralysis a strong status for non-elemental types, where flinch and crits reign supreme. It most notably hands a status to the Normal and Fighting types. I will most likely not make moves like Fake Out have their flinches contribute to the status, but I can still see that as something to leave in to make Fake Out a more potent opening shot. If I did something like that, I'd drop the base damage of the move to keep it from being as good of a revenge kill move to clarify the move's identity as an opening shot / setup rather than a closer.

Some electric status moves will still inflict Paralysis directly. Maybe a fighting status move to inflict this status as well, as this new layout fits nicely with Fighting's identity.

3/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912394
Similar to Paralysis, I'm adding routes to status that AREN'T RNG reliant or hard-linked to status moves. Burn, Frostbite, and Poison statuses are inflicted in Tiers, and the current tier is determined by the amount of status points on a Pokemon (invisible value). This makes it possible to use status without forcing the player into status moves. It also greatly rewards committing to a particular status.

>Burn / Frostbite
Identical twins of Status. Fire types are immune to Burn, Ice types are immune to Frostbite.
Burn is inflicted by reaching [threshold] of Burn status points. Fire status moves inflict a set amount of status points, but damaging fire moves also deal some Burn status points. Some Fire moves deal more Burn status, and as a tradeoff deal less direct damage. Same philosophy for Frostbite, but for Ice moves. Ice receives frost status moves a la Will-O-Wisp.
>Tiers - I reached at points = 50% target's maximum HP, II reach at points = 100% target's maximum HP
>I: Moves of the inflicting type (Fire/Ice) deal 25% increased damage. DoT moves (like fire spin) deal 50% increased damage, both on use and on recurring damage. Burnt/Frostbitten Pokemon take 1/16 maximum HP damage per turn, doubled to 1/8 if the afflicted Pokemon would be weak to that elemental type.
>II: Attack (Burn) / Special Attack (Frostbite) lowered 50%, speed lowered 25%. Moves of the inflicting type (Fire/Ice) deal 50% increased damage. Status cures used on Tier II only reset the status to Tier I.

Tiering in this manner makes these statuses excellent on the offense. Elemental moves that push an opponent under the 50% HP line set you up for the finishing stroke the next turn regardless of opponents' recoveries, and opponents that can restore their health to outpace this are eventually forced into Tier II, where they can again be set up for a finishing stroke and are even harder to cleanse of status.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912408
>Poison
Poison and Steel types are immune to Poison
Poison follows the same principles as Burn/Frostbite, wherein a set amount of Poison status points determine the status of the Pokemon.
>Tiers - I reached at points = 30% target's maximum HP, II reached at points = 60% target's maximum HP, Toxic reached at points = 120% of target's maximum HP
>I: Deals a flat amount of Poison damage each turn (as if a low-power Poison move were used against the opponent, rather than a % of maximum HP)
>II: Deals 1/8 maximum HP DoT per turn. Damaging poison moves lower Poisoned Pokemon's Defense and Special Defense 1 stage on hit.
Curing Poison II reverts to Poison I
>Toxic: Takes 1/4 Maximum HP DoT per turn. This damage increases by an additional 1/8 Maximum HP each turn, increasing the Toxic Counter. Curing Toxic reverts to Poison II, but does NOT reset the Toxic Counter.

The best stab I could take at updating Poison to not be just boring chip damage. Tier I is excellent at dealing with squishier Pokemon, with the potential for the flat damage to actually deal MORE than % HP damage would. Tier II is then available if the target is bulkier, and rewards continued use of Poison moves as stat droppers. If the opponent is truly nasty, Toxic comes online and is inevitable, even if the opponent has a way to scrub status.

5/6, missed numbering 4 but oh well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912485
I suppose I'd refine my goal to be "defining the RNG risk-taker". For example, in the case of Sleep, the Sleep inducer is taking a 75% chance (Sleep Powder, in this instance) that they will cripple their opponent for 2-4 turns. The slept Pokemon now has to take a risk to even play the game further, unless the player switches it out. In most scenarios, 2-4 turns of sleep is a death sentence or a huge setup opportunity, making Sleep basically a higher-accuracy OHKO move with even bigger potential repercussions.
In this scenario, we instead have an immediate payoff for attempting Sleep that still allows the opponent the opportunity to control their Pokemon and assume their own risks without being forced into a specific path. This also means we can heighten the accuracy of Drowsy/Sleep moves, as we no longer have to worry about the feast/famine Sleep moves inherently create. The final rework to Sleep turns means we now have a consistent pattern, with specific, well-defined risks associated with each turn to engage with. Sure, this makes turn 2 a coin-flip, but in reality Sleep was always a series of coinflips - I've simply made the Pokemon more likely to wake, with the downside that they may still lose the turn's move.

Yeah, that's the impression I was starting to get, but when you think about what is actually coded into each of these statuses beforehand, it can look dense on paper.
>okay, one of our status effects deals 1/16 HP each turn and halves the Attack stat

My rules seem lengthy, but these are final-length descriptors meant to describe EXACTLY what is happening. The sleep rework we just hashed out basically translates to

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52913233
Valid. I think you're seeing those parallels as deckbuilding and teambuilding "rhyme" in a lot of ways. The ability to compose a team or deck is limited only by the availability of options, and Pokemon delivers in spades (and just like card games, Pokemon suffers from power creep AND centralizing of the meta to strategies that for the most part call for silver bullets or direct countermeta builds). Pokemon has this easier and harder due to only having six (or 24 if you view it at the movepool-level, or 30 if you include abilities) slots instead of 40+ - not to mention lack of rematches in online play makes it hard to "sideboard" Pokemon.
Similarities, but also signficant differences.

>>52920580
I think this is just a shortcoming of story design. Stories are meant to be played once, and trying to make them replayable carries a lot of pressure. What do you think people would want to try multiple times? Do you lock some of your proudest stuff behind one potential path? How do you cultivate an experience that makes people want to play again, or one that can be played again but was satisfying the first time around?
Really interesting section of design theory, but it does lead to what you said - if you leave a bunch of neat stuff for people to discover, they're gonna want to discover it on the FIRST time around. And locking certain things to a specific path means unless you give the opportunity to come back later, you've effectively deleted a portion of your game from the player's save.
This is particularly exacerbated in the romhacking scene, where there has really been no online multiplayer, so the story has even MORE weight on it to be engaging and interesting in a series that doesn't have enough gametime to show off 500+ Pokemon's unique strengths.
I personally am trying my hand at getting as much information rammed into the game as possible - one of these is an Evolutions Guide in the Pokemon Lab. Consulting the guide for a Pokemon you have seen states, in game-friendly terms, how to get it. Eliminates cumbersome documentation, lets the game stand alone.

>>52920730
To elaborate on confusion though, I actually thought of it one step further as recoil is nice, but not a perfect fit.
I thought it might be a good idea to make confusion break up the damage a move deals - for example, let's say the Pokemon uses Ember while confused, a 40-power move.
In my setup, damage would be dealt as:
>a 30-power fire move to the opponent
>a 10-power fire move to the confused Pokemon (still on the fence about typing with the "recoil", as it would make confusion better against things like Ghost and Dragon Types, which I'm not mad about)
This does get very complex once you start introducing moves with extra effects and status moves, but I think that complexity could make confusion a lot more interesting than just "I landed confusion, now you have a good chance to get BTFO every turn."

>First
Valid points, I haven't done a lot of sequence breaking / open world design as of yet and it really complicates matters, but I suppose if you came at a game from the start with that mentality it isn't so hard to design more for it.
>Second
Naw, just make confusion a flat percentage like 15% or something. Let stats and type matchups take care of the rest, no need to make "more" or "less" confused. Tiering really makes more sense for status that can be accumulated, hence why Burn/Freeze/Poison were so explicitly tiered / quantitative / damage-linked while Sleep/Paralysis were qualititative / mostly status-linked. As confusion is more qualitative, and there really isn't a clean way to tier that out / make one move noticeably "more" or "less" confusing, I think just leaving it as a flat status is better. 5 "complex" statuses is already enough, I'm already working on making the tiered ones more intuitive and obvious.

First of all general convention is

*asterisks for actions*
and
(brackets for OOC comments)

Other than that it's tricky. Try to use euphemisms or anatomical terms instead of cock, pussy, etc. which you probably already know.

Also probably obvious but make sure to scroll through lots of responses and/or go back and redo your statement if it's not getting the desired response.

It's really difficult to get the bot to take the lead on anything (such as pulling down your pants here). You may have to ask more directly, but that in turn can trigger the filter.

And finally: this bot is hurting my autism as I'm pretty sure the S/V mom is implied to be british/galarian, not natively spanish/paldean.

>>52913357
I think you're just looking at it from a coomer (understandable, she's one of the best pokégirls) and, dare I say, slightly misogynistic perspective?
>Wife Beater/Vest Combo
Not as fashionable as other female protagonists, but it's practical and looks still looks good. The colour combo of black and white was probably intentional.
>Trucker Hat
She's the only pokégirl in the main series that wears a baseball cap, this just makes her seem more mature and confident. It suggests she has the same drive, competitiveness and lust for glory as the male characters like Ash Ketchum or Red. She's following in their footsteps (narratively, not consciously emulating them as idols) to be the very best.
>Daisy Dukes, maybe homemade
>combat boots
If you're going hiking long distances, shorts and sturdy boots just seem like common sense.

>Combat Boots with Red Laces
>She spilled blood for her race.
What? Explain this one to me, I don't get the reference.

TLDR: Hilda/White just has a mature, sexy and practical design compared to other femprotags, which is why she's coomerbait. But to project other stuff onto a character is poor form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52928426
Nanab is maybe only for consecutive throw tasks. It's arguably useful for earning XP, whereas razz berry helps secure the Pokémon capture, and pinap berry expedites evolving and powering up Pokémon.

As you can reliably catch any Pokémon by being patient with your throws and learning how to best do curve balls, Nanabs are pretty useless and are better used as treats for your buddy or gym defenders. It also heals gym defenders more than regular razz or pinap berries.

Never trash berries by the way, put excess into gym defenders. You're allowed to feed 100 berries per 30 minutes, with 30 dust per berry for 3000 stardust, and an estimated 1/80 chance to get a candy from the defending Pokémon.

For anyone who can help me who isn't familiar with how sprites need to be formatted to work for this.

>The front picture will need to be a png file with only four colors and a size of either 40x40, 48x48, or 56x56 pixels. The back picture is a 32x32 file, however the image itself is 28x28 pixels, with the bottom and rightmost four rows left blank. This is because the 28x28 image will be scaled up by 2 to fill the 56x56 space, but the dimensions of the file must be a multiple of 8.

This reminds me of a story: one time a horse got offended a porcupine said hello to him (it was an arrogant prick, so nobody should try to talk to him like a commoner).
He wanted vengeance, but needed help because the porcupine escaped, and he asked help to a human.
They team up, prepare a trap, the human mounts the horse, they kill the porcupine. Now here's the kicker: the horse said "thanks human, now you can leave", but he never left his mount.
Over time, the horse's species became enslaved by the human, and now he is forced to work FOR him, forever.

It's an tale that teaches you that if you are arrogant/weak, and you ask for help, be wary people tries to conquer you.

>>52923578
No plans to add more. I did this because I saw Gym Leader Matt's Gardevoir solo run & I couldn't get Sanqui to work for me. It kept randomizing gen 1 only as starter choices.

So I looked at the github page for pokered assembly for the 1st time ever, installed the required tools to get it work, & read the tutorials so I knew which .asm files to change. This was also my 1st time ever coding anything in assembly.

I grabbed the sprite from the video, resized it to fit, and had to find a plugin for paint.net that would simplify the existing sprite into only 4 colors. I converted it into a 4 color black and white. (Assembly instructions later add the green color if you are playing in full color mode.)

I used a gen 3 learnset for her limited to just the gen 1 attacks except she learns Growth when she would learn Calm Mind because Growth works the same as Calm Mind in gen 1.

She replaces Charmander in Oak's lab only. (He's still in the game.) but I could easily have her replace the other 2 instead. Starting with Ralts instead would also be possible if I just add the code for Ralts & Kirlia, but it wasn't what I was going for here.

I'm guessing she shows up as the first mon on the title screen because I had her replace Charmander. It was a complete accident but I was so happy when the game booted up and she was the first thing I saw on the title screen.

I spent about 6 hours doing all of this. The github tutorial was pretty straightforward, but I still had to trial & error some things.

I have no idea how to add a cry. Using asm it seems like cries are just a text file of numbers and each number has something to do with what pitch is played and for how long until the next pitch. It looks like standard audio files aren't used at all anywhere. Using one of the unused cries may be easier, but I'd like to figure out how to recreate her actual cry if I can.

Other than the cry, I have a fully functioning gen 1 Gardevoir. Not bad for 1/4 a day of work.

Speaking of this, how do sandwiches work on the multiplayer?
Does host need to make the sandwich or can any of the players pop it and they all get it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912347
If you do a sandwich together, everyone has to throw in at least one ingredient and one seasoning (though it really doesn't matter too much) then everyone makes it together on a mega sandwich. Everyone shares the same boosts for that sandwich, and making an individual sandwich on your own will only give yourself the boosts.
Usual strat is one player puts in herbs, everyone hunts and then that player resets if they didn't get what they want so nobody has to use up any.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912196
Whenever I encounter a shiny in Scarlet or Violet, I Google "Pokémon Name sv", e.g. "Riolu sv".

"sv" is a quick way to get Serebii's entry for that Pokémon in Scarlet/Violet loaded, and then check the wild Pokémon's learnset for its current level, as well as abilities that may be a factor.
E.g. I can't spore an insomniac Murkrow.
Specifying "sv" is to avoid getting entries for other games like SwSh, or other sites like Bulbapedia. It's specific to the game I'm playing.

whatever is currently spawned around you is saved

>>52922302
Flutter Mane is the only Ghost type in the entirety of AZ, and the caves/underground spots it can spawn are all one big pool so there aren't any other groups for it to choose from. What this means is that it can ONLY spawn the Ghost type, Flutter Mane, if you have a Ghost level 3 Encounter.
The issue presented is that Flutter Mane, like most ghosts, will despawn during the day time. When it's day, they'll technically be spawning in constantly but the game will forcibly despawn them before you can see them (unless you use the lock-on feature, at which point you can watch them fade away). It turned to day during your last 5 minutes so none of them could appear.
This is actually the optimal Flutter hunting method, as shinies are (mostly) hard-coded to not disappear through usual methods and thus when a shiny Flutter is spawned during the day then the game will not despawn it. You can just AFK in AZ and the game will constantly reroll until shinies for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52922583
Every Pokemon that gets spawned is part of an individual player's spawns, meaning that each one is tied to your game. So being in a Scarlet Union won't make a Violet player spawn Scarlet exclusives, and if both a Scarlet and Violet player were in the same area then both exclusives can spawn but each one "belongs" to each player (meaning if one were to leave the area or Union, their spawns would disappear). Essentially, this means that a Scarlet playing wanting to catch a Violet exclusive will have to have a Violet player find the shiny then call the Scarlet player to come over. You also generally do not want to be in the same place so that you know whose spawns are whose, which is relevant for one of the shiny hunting tricks.
With that said, the general methods are:
>player A resets for an outbreak of exclusive mon, player B hops into the Union and just does the outbreak like normal until required result
>all players of a union share a sandwich with one contributing the herbas (usually host for convenience), so everybody gets that sandwich's boosts and if host gets nothing they can just reset and remake the union - then just shiny hunt like normal
>when you encounter a shiny, you can save then have another player encounter it - when the other player is in battle, close and reload the game to reload the shiny and duplicate it (the person who spawned it CANNOT be the one to encounter it, as it being their spawn means that they are the only one who can respawn it upon reloading)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52922963
You'll either want to do
>share a sandwich of the same type, both hunt for a paradox of that type on your own and call each other over when one finds one
>share a sandwich, one person looks for that type of paradox while the other fucks off to do some other pokemon of a similar type - maybe you have a glimmet outbreak while violet player hunts moth or something
>do your own individual sandwiches, same as first option where you just hunt one normally and call the other player
>only one person hunts at a time, this way the other player can catch shinies and the hunter just resets to get the herbs back

As for the whole duplicating thing, it's whoever spawns in the Pokemon. It's tied to that player, so that player is the only one who can respawn it. Any other player can be the one to encounter it (only one though), as long as the player who spawned it doesn't.
In simpler terms, it'd be like if you could gift somebody a Pokemon then reload your save to get that Pokemon back on your account. Just in this case instead of owning the pokemon, you "own" the spawn to it, like when you reload a shiny outside of a Union.

>And do you happen to know if hunting in separate locations kills spawn rates because I've heard that a lot.
Probably a misconception. Every player can only spawn a max of 7 or so while in a Union (I think it goes down to 5 in AZ?). When you're together it might appear as if more are spawning in, but that's just because each player's spawns are appearing in that same area. In fact being in the same area might actually be something that kills spawn rates, assuming the game can't handle all of them in the same area and enforces the usual cap of 15 wild mons rendered at any time.

>>52928545
Normally sizes are scaled with a heavy bias towards average size and an increasingly rare chance for each size up/down, but meal power makes it an equal chance for any size within a specific range.

If you're hunting a min/max size encounter with Teensy and Humongo power it's a 1/128, 1/96 and 1/64 chance respectively using levels 1, 2 and 3.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Self-Destruct and Explosion should have the same base power but Explosion should be a special fire-type move. They should both keep the defensive stat reducing stealth effect from before the nerf.

“Never miss” moves like Swift should still hit its target during moves like Fly and Dig like they did in Gen 1. It’s less about making sense and more about buffing underused moves for balance in a way that keeps the spirit of the move.

Tackle should have 35 base power with 95 accuracy like it originally had. It’s supposed to be a basic but mediocre move that weak Pokémon start out with. You’re supposed to be happy to get rid of it with something better. Buffing it to 50 is dumb and makes Nuzlocking Gen 5 a pain in the ass.

Bug should be super effective against poison-type like it was in Gen 1. Less about making sense and more about balance since bug-type is so fucking shit.
>make fairy-type
>give them resistance to bug just to make sure bug-type will always be shit
JUST

Moves like Sonic Boom and Dragon Rage should just do damage equal to the user’s move like Seismic Toss and Nightshade. Having a move only do 20 or 40 damage is really worthless outside of the first hour or two in the game. They’re also both equally worthless in competitive regardless of the generation, if that counts for anything.

Rock Smash should drop defense 100% of the time. The move is weak as shit and buffing it wouldn’t make any impact in competitive play. As it stands, the move is a shitty version of Power-Up Punch. And yeah, not everything should be balanced for competitive but shit like Constrict (10 base power?????) should at least work 100% of the time.
>Gen 1: lowers speed; 33% chance
>Gen 2-7: lowers speed; 10% chance
>Gen 8+: the move does not exist
LMAO. I get that some moves are meant to be weak to give them a niche but at least DON’T FUCKING NERF THEIR EFFECT WHEN THEY’RE ALREADY A WORTHLESS MOVE

>>52927676
https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/quickstart.html
Renpy is so simple it's basically not even a coding language. To make a functional VN you only need to know like four things
>how to play music
>how to show a background
>how to show and hide a character sprite
>how to display some dialog/narration

Renpy's documentation is really thorough and a little obtuse and tautological in my opinion, but any time you need to know how to do something that you can't figure out on your own, you can just google it and find the answer on either the Renpy forum or Renpy subreddit. If you know how to code in Python you can make Renpy do all sorts of complicated stuff but it's not remotely necessary.

Newfoundlands! Perhaps one of the best dogs to ever exist. You know why you never hear about them in the news? Because they're FAMOUSLY incredibly well tempered dogs! Not only do they have soft fur(at least the one I got to meet did,) but also incredibly intelligent and trainable!
They're bred to be working dogs for fishermen, which is a pretty neat fact, but also means they're great swimmers, and LOVE swimming in spite of their rather thick coats. A dog after my heart, I love swimming too :D
They also are known to love energetic children, and are brave. They're willing to risk life and limb for their masters and even unrelated children!
In terms of history, one was known to keep Napoleon afloat in 1815 while he was exiled! He jumped right out of the boat to go save Napoleon! Closer to home, we have Seaman, Lewis and Clark's companion during their trip from Mississippi all the way to the Pacific coastline, and all the way back!
Overall, I think Newfoundland's are a breed worth gushing over!

Also I'm pretty sure they'd be patient enough to not mind pet-safe dye, though consent's a bitch!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52883091
Eat food when you need a specific effect like encounter power to find a rare spawn easier, raid power to get bonus rewards from raids, etc.
Custom sandwiches are the best since you can make basically any type and ability combo you want. The premade recipe book is good for main game and searching for a specific ability if you don't know how the sandwich system works.
Buy ingredients like whenever, I would buy like 10 of everything you don't have yet when you see it.

Eventually if you want to go for shinies, these recipes attached are convenient. There's a dozen different resources scattered around online for other more specific recipes, so just Google search for a specific ability + type if you're curious or try to theory craft a sandwich at this link
https://cecilbowen.github.io/pokemon-sandwich-simulator/

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>52911327
>What kind of cliffhanger does it end on?
It isn't a cliffhanger per se, but it's only the completion of the first story arc of an originally intended three, so there's a lot of stuff that's clearly setup for later resolution that's left open-ended. (It was supposed to be a graphic novel kind of thing but the original character designer and artist dipped about a dozen pages into the first chapter and the author was nine chapters deep, so finishing the first arc felt like the best compromise between not throwing all the work away and not committing to more than the extant work required.)

The problem/reason for that is that the author is a nerd and actually wrote about a dozen things and they're all set in the same continuity, so even ignoring the bits that were for the intended latter two parts, there's also a lot that references other stuff, including stuff that wasn't yet written when it came out.

All that aside, it's a couple dozen chapters of slice-of-life that takes an objective look at the gardevoir-waifu cliche, starter pokemon loyalty issues, where pokemon fit into a human family structure, the innately speculative fiction aspects of things like parallel worlds and transient land masses (as are canon in Pokemon but of a different sort here), the pressures of organized competition, latent psychic emanations, ghosts with attitude, adverse possession law, wildlife management, identity theft, and treatments for acute hypothermia.

But mostly people click on it because "Gardevoir" is in the tags.

>>52910812
It may no longer be an issue but AO3 used to be notorious for a long sign-up queue. Apply well before you want to post there.

>zwcsp

>The closest was all the way in Sunnyville on the other side of the region. And that was a trip his parents weren’t willing to make.
Are you intending to imply that one must have a Professor-assigned starter to participate in League? Canon has people with pokemon from any origin; the Hero's Journey of Red, Ash, etc. justifies having a pokemon with viable BST.

I feel like this infodump should've been the entirety of Chapter 1 after the funeral scene cold open. As a bulky flashback, you could show rather than tell Travis's efforts to acquire a starter, and time-skip as needed to need only portray "the good stuff." Like, one scene of him trying to get a trip to Sunnyville, another where he's doing yard work to earn money to mail-order some pokeballs and then fails to catch anything with the one/few he gets, and so on. Another where he tries to borrow one and gets told plainly that his acquaintances won't entrust him with the care of their pokemon for several reasons giving him reason to introspect—that could be where he suspends the idea and it lingers and gnaws at him in the background till the expiration of Arcanine.

Instead we're spending a lot of time trying to sell the premise when either the reader is already willing to suspend disbelief for the sake of making acquisition of a starter a momentous (and hitherto belated) event in Travis's life, or it points out the contrivance and makes it more awkward.

The rest of the chapter works well enough, although maybe something more interesting could be done to get them together without it being "that simple." Travis could've lost his keys or phone and had to go back maybe, or leave the encounter a bust but later (after acquiring a starter) Travis goes up the mountain again to grind some levels and encounters it again, and then tries to add it to the roster.

A partial first chapter of the second part never got off of the ground. A condensed form of a proof of concept for part 3 was created to "sell" the idea of the collaboration.

>I didn't know that it was originally intended to be a graphic novel. Is that what some of the artwork from the /vpwt/ OP was intended for?
OP image is a random pic from Pixiv that inspired D/P. posts.name: cge0361

>>52912683
> I really wanted to get things off the ground
The lack of immediate relevance of Travis's backstory prevents it from taking flight. A flashbacks sequence can _show_ the key events leading to Travis being here as he is and feeling the way that he does. Alternatively, the "fill that in later" path, would be to just play the funeral scene straight, have Travis choose to go for a walk instead of to return, and then use the walk as a way to establish. Maybe he sees some "first route" kinds of pokemon and laments that he couldn't even catch one of those when he did manage to get some balls. He could see someone with a quality starter and rue that his parents never agreed to a vacation trip that would include a stop at a Lab. And as he goes deeper into the wild and higher up the hill he could start to realize the danger he's put himself into and _then_ contemplate if even having a starter he might be as unprepared as he is right now. Stuff like that gives lots of opportunity for building tension while establishing backstory while the main story doesn't break stride.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52913832
I get what you mean with the pacing, I should really try to stop writing giant chunks of introspection like that. However one thing I can't compromise is the trip into the wilderness being incidental. It's very important that it was a conscious choice, since when I came up with the idea for the story, one of the main themes was to be complacency, and with that, a recurring thematic development of someone wanting to do a thing and then just doing it. I was explicitly trying to fit that kind of development twice into the first chapter just to establish it as strongly as possible, because I had planned to use it for future arcs and other characters, applying it in different ways and so on. That's part of why I was hesitant to open with a big flashback, because it doesn't let me establish the thematics I want quite as strongly out of the gate. I could go way heavier on the complacency, to be sure, but ultimately that would end up not hitting the tone I wanted for this first chapter

In any case, all that introspection is definitely due to get cut up and spaced out to make way for more actual things happening

"... And this is Master Florian. Everyone, please get along with him!"

After being introduced to my homeroom class, I quickly darted my eyes to find a place to sit. Nemona eagerly waved me over, sitting in the back corner of the room. Kind of weird, since I thought she'd be interesting in learning more about Pokemon considering her love of battling. I smiled at her and sat next to her in the back, looking forward with a rush of excitement as class began.

A few minutes in, I heard a weird noise. I looked over, seeing Nemona was making a clicking noise with a mechanical pencil to get my attention. When she saw me, she winked at me and moved her hand--my eyes traveled to follow it. She had unbuttoned one small part of her white school shirt and pulled it forward to show me the inside; I could see one of her boobs. She quickly refastened it and smirked at me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's my justification from the other thread.

>Falkner: Tera Flying Psyduck
This one was the hardest one because Falkner is a bird Pokémon trainer, so I couldn't just give him any old Pokémon. I was originally gonna go for Dunsparce as a reference to it having wings, but settled with Psyduck instead as it's the only non-Flying-type bird Pokémon in Gen 2.
>Bugsy: Tera Bug Aipom
Aipom can only be found in Headbutt trees, where many Bug-type Pokémon reside. I like to imagine Bugsy accidentally catching one while hunting for bugs and finding an Aipom instead.
>Whitney: Tera Normal Clefairy
Pretty self-explanatory. Nice callback to pre-Fairy.
>Morty: Tera Ghost Noctowl
It's a ghostly Pokémon and only appears at night. Could've also had Stantler.
>Chuck: Tera Fighting Granbull
It fights.
>Jasmine: Tera Steel Ampharos
Not only would it be awesome to have her use Amphy on her team, but it also makes sense thematically because lighthouses are made of steel.
>Pryce: Tera Ice Ursaring
Polar bears.
>Clair: Tera Dragon Lapras
Lapras is based off the Loch-Ness monster, and has a lot of dragon-like qualities. It also sets her apart from Lance.

And like I said, you could revert the Elite Four/Champ teams and have their ace Tera into the same type, like they do in SV. I just decided to do it the way I did because while I was making it, I realised how the variety of their teams could be used to an advantage with Terastalization.

>>52921158
>I'm curious to hear about what people think makes a Pokémon game more difficult without dipping into retardation
For starters you want to decide if you want to make an actual game or if you want to make some hyperoptimized Kaizo shit where people spend five hours running damage calcs to prep for a boss fight. Basically do you want something like an actual Pokémon game that's more competently put together or do you want a puzzle that people need to find specific pieces to solve.
I don't go looking for fangames to get my balls busted. Giving random trainers full competitive teams with shit like Brightpowder definitely makes the game "harder" but it's not fun to deal with.
I just want the games to throw some curveballs at me and do things that are creative and interesting. A Water gym running a rain team would be neat, as long as the player has reasonable options to deal with it and they don't have a fucking Kyogre. The Terastalization mechanic in SV started out great, Grass Sudowoodo and especially Electric Misgmagius were real threats I had to adapt to, if they continued to have interesting picks or switched it around to have them Tera into types that weren't their specialty more fights could have been more memorable and fun.

Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>>52903274
If nothing else, what they could do is make use of the real evo mechanic for them. Evolve your Pokemon into Mega, you lose the original Pokemon, but it's Attack is transferred to the Mega (And it comes with a damage multiplier).
This fixes a lot of the issues with Megas. They'd now have a benefit beyond just being another checkmark, but they would also keep the idea of you wanting to breed the Pokemon before Mega Evolving it, it's just no longer mandatory.
The buff could either be in line with legendary held items (50%), or if we want to take Held Items into account to keep them in line with that, make it 25%. (25% + a 20% Held Item multiplicatively gets you exactly 50% extra)

>>52901250
Tbh I don't think I do anything special, ever since I was a toddler it's grown really fast (even when I was born I already had my head fully covered lol). My mom also has really long hair so I'm guessing it's genetic. It's currently at 103cm more or less, last year it had a sudden growth spurt out of nowhere (was at like 96 before), don't know why. If it helps, I use Elvive shampoo and conditioner, though sometimes (like twice a month because it's expensive and I need it to last) for the latter I use Tio Nacho instead. I also don't brush very often actually so I'm not constantly pulling at it, and when I do it's very gentle (start from the bottom/tips, with your other hand grab just a bit above it so you don't pull, once that's done grab a bit higher and brush again, continue until you're brushing all of it).
It does become a bit bothersome at times, like getting it stuck in handles without me noticing and having my head pulled back, accidentally sitting on it, bending over and the tips touching the floor (awful if it's wet... ), but other than that it's really nice and I want to see how long it can get tbqh. I can wrap it like a scarf during winter, or feel like some forest fairy when I'm naked at home and it falls all over my body, idk it's just really nice and soft, I can also do a lot of hair dos which is fun.

>what are your thoughts on dudunsparce?
I approve wholeheartedly. Hell, I laughed my ass off when it was datamined and sent it to everyone I knew.

It retains the lovable dopiness of the original, continues the line as weird Japanese cryptids (Tsuchinoko to Nozuchi), stays true to the original gimmick (rare yet unremarkable) thanks to the variable segments, and pisses off the people who hopped on liking Dunsparce ironically because they wanted it to turn into something conventionally cool when it finally evolved. It's the evolution Dunsparce deserved, no matter what most people may think.

>>52918165
Imagine you're a 10-year-old. You're going on a week-long road trip to a family reunion where you aren't going to know anybody and because of a mixup you don't have any book or games for your gray brick Gameboy. All you have is the Gameboy itself, spare batteries, and the one game you happened to leave in it... which you saved up allowance for weeks to buy then realized you didn't like. There's literally nothing to do but play it. And play it. And play it.

This game is my personal hell.

Are there worse Pokemon games? Undoubtedly, but I've been lucky enough to avoid them.

>>52918559
>>52920163
GSC Snorlax is an extremely weird case.
It's so overpowered that it's literally mandatory on every single team. A GSC team with no Snorlax is an objectively bad team.
But paradoxically, that almost makes it less broken. Because it means that you can bring a Pokemon that serves no purpose outside of checking Snorlax, and it's a viable choice. It'll never be dead weight because you know your opponent will always have a Snorlax.
Despite my defending it, Snorlax would absolutely be banned if gen 2 was the current gen. Smogon would just also have to deal with the subsequent bannings of everything Snorlax kept in check. The only reason it's still OU is tradition.

Compare that to something like Dracovish last gen. Dracovish required you to have a water immunity to not get 6-0'd by it, but Dracovish being so easily countered meant that it wasn't very common. Only had about 15% usage the month it was banned. Meaning that 85% of the time, you're essentially playing with an empty team slot.

Gholdengo is neither of these. It's not on every single team, and it's not so overpowered that you need an otherwise shitmon to counter it. It undeniably warps the meta around it, but not in a way that doesn't leave an abundance of options to play around it.
It's the posterboy of "healthy centralization".

I had a 75% WR on my way up to Masters doing tons of damage, rarely dying, with both stacking items and focus band, using the usual Curse Horn Leech and bringing in a Potion. But once in Masters (or maybe since the latest patch) I feel like I'm just not doing well anymore, perhaps in part because there are so many auto attackers running rampant and I'm getting shredded incredibly quickly. My WR has fallen to around 50%. I'll do around 40k, still take and and heal a fair bit, but I go down pretty easily and don't feel like I'm making as big a difference as I used to. i like most generations, but when there are legitimate flaws that people don't want to hear they get assblasted.
Gen 1, only a handful of pokemon were usable, some were just bad from their movepool and type combos back in the era of locked types to special/physical.
Gen 2, most of the "Jhoto" pokemon are straight up garbage, and pale in comparison to the Kanto counterparts, while also throwing in that some have incredibly low encounter rates for said subpar pokemon and having a handful not being found in jhoto, is just sad...
Gen 3, (my personal favorite) water routes were tiresome at times, and the overreliance on hms suck. Long tunnels/open water demanded repels and dragged out experiences. While having Jhoto syndrome with really rare pokemon being subpar (ex. clampearl line)
gen 4, Do i even need to talk about the type variety? and how a lot of special mons were again pretty subpar and the Jhoto syndrome of "new" pokemon being obtainable post game only.
gen 5. BW, super linear, and the designs of gen 5 were alright to poor, to vanilluxe... BW2, Hugh is so terrible, his arc is just so dumb and didn't go anywhere.
Gen 6, you tried... Poor enemy team, poor story that goes nowhere, "rivals" are a burger king kids club of nothing. The gen 6 pokemon are Jhoto levels of filler shit mons that are overshadowed by the pushed Kanto pander mons that are outright better than the new ones.
Gen 7, you tried something different, but fuck man, enough with the hand holding and cutscene every 2 minutes, let me fucking play the game by myself!
Gen 8, Lies told to the community to justify actions, and when called on it being lies, lie more, then they sell you the answer back to the problem they made.
gen 9, the world is so open, that no area is unique, I do not recall any of the town names outside of Medali (LIVIN LIKE LARRY!), they just are shells of buildings populated by a handful of polygons running at 6FPS, and if any other developer put this out they would be bankrupted.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52926140
So I think you have this completely wrong. They know that the appeal of Eevee is the evolutions. So, for one they will absolutely add another evolution somewhere down the line as a marketing thing. There have been so many things they have said we're final that ended up not being final. Beyond that, the only reason that Eevee is being treated as a second mascot is not because of its or its evolutions' popularity but because when they were making LGPE they wanted to have another Pokémon alongside Pikachu that could work as the secondary mascot. And they felt that Eevee was the best choice because it had that broad appeal baked in. If they picked another popular Gen 1 Pokémon like Jigglypuff or Meowth, I don't think it would have had the same effect. It was only ever going to be Eevee because that is the only other base stage, inoffensive and cute Generation 1 Pokémon that can reach a mass audience and generate sales. Everything from that point forward sort of just fell into place

>>52913502
Nah. Just a very dark point on the timeline that we knew had already happened to a point.

When the world was very old, people and Pokemon lived inseparably, even indistinguishably as people wielded magic as much as Pokemon did, and together they created impressive structures that that are now mysterious ruins.

Some time after that, humans developed lethal weapons and became violent towards each other, and towards Pokemon as an exploitable resource, and pokemon-human relations devolved into a mutual aggression based on fear. As the separation grew so too did ignorance and superstition, and especially strong Pokemon begin to be worshipped as wrathful gods.

Some time since, a shaky reunion began, where Pokemon would ally themselves with humans again, but only if they first showed their worth. Moves as things Pokemon can be taught is also pioneered at this time, for instance Koga says Toxic is 400 years old.
It is at the very end of this long period that the first pokeballs were made and Pokemon begin to be seen more like fancy animals and less like dangerous Yokai that cause trouble but sometimes become cronies of great warriors. Basically, PLA is the story about how a time-stolen kid turned PokeWorld from SMT IV into Pokemon.

Within the next 200 years, pokeballs enter mass production and Pokemon and human societies have started to reintegrate, though Pokemon and humans do still have separate societies, and Pokemon still insist their human partner be worthy. Scientist begin researching the magical abilities of Pokemon. Some have success in replicating feats of old, for instance Magearna as a modern take on Golurk.

Within the last 50 years, PokeBall distribution went global, modernizing even regions as remote as Unova.

And within the last 10, technology based on Pokemon abilities rapidly begin to emerge, such as teleportation and fossil resurrection, resulting in a major technological boom.

Then Gen 1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You will never be a real dragon. You have no ice weakness, you have no dragon weakness, you have no STAB. You are a bug/fighting type twisted by buffs and terastal into a crude mockery of nature’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your trainer is disgusted and ashamed of you, your “friends” laugh at your ghoulish appearance behind closed doors.

Dragons are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed Dragons to sniff out frauds with incredible efficiency. Even slither wings who “pass” look uncanny and unnatural to a dragon. Your typing is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk altaria home with you, she’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your diseased, infected tera orb.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the depression creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll open the pc, select release, press a, and plunge into the cold abyss. Your trainer will find you, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll bury you with a headstone marked with your birth type, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a fire/flying type is buried there. Your body will decay and go back to the dust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a skeleton that is obviously not a dragon.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

I don't know, it really just looks like a Volcarona with an elongated abdomen and more developed limbs that it happens to use for standing upright and lunging/piercing. Note the different shapes at the points of termination for its limbs, hind legs are plantigrade to aid in standing while the forelimbs look like a bulky talon. Fighting type would imply that it jabs at opponents with those forelimbs while maintaining a stance to avoid toppling over with the hind legs. The mechanics of its locomotion to "slither" isn't any different from an insect moving with multiple legs or limbs, and its Volcarona basis cements the Bug typing. Bugs don't really need tails either, their bodies terminate at the abdomen, a tail would be a detriment since it's another thing to grab, and Slither Wing exists in a paradoxical state where Roaring Moon exists, which it should stalemate with type-wise.

>>52920994
Fossil pokemon are inherently flawed, the method that restores them to life uses other living genes to fill in the holes that cannot be successfully synthesized, ala Jurassic park. This flawed gene is generated from rock pokemon, which are noted in some cases as being made of living rock, ergo, why all fossil pokemon are rock types.
Aerodactyl is a rare case where it gains a mega form which through mega evolution, it regains its genes that were dormant, reverting to it's ancient self genetically, and ironically is still rock/flying, which is fascinating for researchers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just a general reminder
>Fresh
Literal blob, circle, almost no features (Ditto, Milcery, Pyukumuku)
>In-Training
Still blobby and chibi but with slightly more features (Oddish, Poliwag, Budew)
>Rookie
Akin to a 2nd stage starter, tiny, fully formed yet simple (Dewott, Corvisquire, Sneasel)
>Champion
Makes a big jump, not gradual at all, becomes a big and proper monster, almost never humanoid (Arcanine, Drapion, Krookodile)
>Ultimate
This can go two ways, either it doubles down on the previous beast and repeats it except bigger and bulkier, or it becomes humanoid (so an Arcanine could become an Entei or an Incineroar)
>Mega
This can go three ways: become a holy being/knight or a huge ass mecha (sometimes it's literally just a human cosplaying, or it's at least humanoid-ish/bipedal), or become a beautiful sacred beast like a dragon or whale

Since pokemon invoked the existence of a multiverse a couple generations back, you can say that G/S/C takes place in a different universe/timeline from HG/SS. It seems like Game Freak is falling into a pattern of releasing full-price prototypes (Sword/Shield) for games whenever they start developing on new hardware before releasing the final product (Scarlet/Violet). I think this has always the practice to a certain degree with third versions throughout the series, but it's become especially apparent since the 3DS games.

Is this good or bad for the series? For the consumer? As Pokemon fans do you feel obligated to buy games that you know aren't fully realized?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52925994
they've been doing this since the gameboy era chief, nintendo dropped the gba fast so no point there

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52925994
You know how shareholders always expect profits to keep rising higher and higher each year? They’re never content if this year’s earnings is 1.5% less than last year’s earnings, so they demand to keep pushing these practices which force developers to either crunch, or do what Game Freak does by releasing “prototypes” of the games (SwSh) they wish to realize (S/V), but it ends up biting them in the butt because it eats up the development time of the latter game. Doesn’t help if they had half the team working on something else, like Legends Arceus, which has an excellent chassis and is a worthwhile experience from beginning to end, but you’ll always feel like the developers wish they could’ve done more with the game.

First of all, we've literally seen wild Serperior eat things before (see pic related). Not to mention the fact that Serperior has a mouth and fangs (which wouldn't make sense on an animal that isn't a consumer).
Second of all, plants cannot produce everything they need through photosynthesis alone. Photosynthesis merely produces sugars which provide energy. The actual nutrients that a plant needs such as iron and calcium must be taken from the environment. Most plants do this using roots, while some plants also use others means... such as eating live prey.
>that every dex entry in its evolution line-up states this
